--- title: Predictive decisioning 300-level live demo description: Predictive decisioning 300-level live demo tabs: [ 'Demo preparation', 'Demo script'] --- export const Title = () => ( Predictive decisioning
300-level live demo ); ![Predictive decisioning banner](./images/proactive-incident-resolution-300-script-github-banner.jpg)
Introduction
Thank you for attending this Predictive Decisioning demonstration.

Today I’ll show how IBM Cloud Pak for Business Automation uses machine learning to enhance customer retention offers. You will learn how to integrate Watson Studio Machine Learning with the Cloud Pak to predict business outcomes. These predictions are used by automated decision services to target retention policies, lower customer retention costs, and eliminate many paper-based processes.

Business users can quickly get started creating and using predictions to improve their everyday processes.

Let’s get started!
**[Go to top](#top)**
1 - Reviewing the manual call center process
| **1.1** | **Show SkyTalk’s current manual process** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | SkyTalk, a telecommunications provider, is losing many of its best customers to competitors. SkyTalk needs to reduce customer churn. Let’s review the set of written customer retention policies that department management implemented. | | **Action**   1.1.1 | Show SkyTalk’s **Retention offer document**, which was opened during demo preparation.

| | **Narration** | Call center agents were asked to understand various retention offers and manually pick the ‘best’ option to retain the client. This did not work well for a variety of reasons.

• Agents could not factor in unique customer circumstances, and thus offers were not tailored.

• SkyTalk’s retention policy guidelines were implemented inconsistently by call center agents.

• Requiring call center agents to make complex offers in real-time often led to costly decisions.

These factors resulted in skyrocketing customer retention costs, while attrition remained steady.

SkyTalk needed a reliable way to find the lowest cost retention offers. They decided to invest in an automated predictive solution.

This new application leverages decision automation and machine learning to provide customer retention offers in real-time. | **[Go to top](#top)**
2 - Modeling the business rules
| **2.1** | **Review the components of SkyTalk’s retention decisions** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | A business analyst in the customer care division uses machine learning and decision automation technologies to configure the retention offer application. The business analyst writes the business rules to generate retention offer recommendations. | | **Action**   2.1.1 | Access the Business Automation Studio on the IBM Automation home page window opened during demo preparation. Then click **SkyTalk customer retention DS** (DS stands for Decision Service).

| | **Action**   2.1.2 | Click **Open**.                                              

| | **Action**   2.1.3 | Click **SkyTalk Initial retention DS**.                                             

| | **Action**   2.1.4 | Click **Retention offer**.                                                                                            

| | **Narration** | The business analyst creates an automated decision, called a decision service, using a hierarchical model of business rules. Each blue box represents a sub decision. The green shapes represent the input data.

The ‘Determine retention offer’ decision service requires two inputs: ‘Ranked retention offers’ and ‘Retention budget’. These two inputs are derived using predictions.

Let’s take a closer look at one sub decision to see how the decision logic defines how decisions are made. | | **Action**   2.1.5 | Review the **Retention offer decision model** after it opens.                                              

| | **Action**   2.1.6 | Click the **Logical upgrade** box.                                              

| | **Action**   2.1.7 | Click the **Logic** tab.                                              

| | **Action**   2.1.8 | Click **upgrade eligibility table**.                                              

| | **Narration** | The ‘upgrade eligibility criteria’ are expressed in a decision table. Each row corresponds to a specific eligibility criterion expressed with a business rule.

By hovering the cursor on a row, the analyst can review the business rule in natural language. For example, at SkyTalk a Gold customer must have a subscription usage of at least $160 USD to be eligible for a Premium upgrade. | | **Action**   2.1.9 | Show the **upgrade table** decision table. Move the cursor over **row 3** to show the equivalent rule in natural language.

| | **Action**   2.1.10 | Click **Back to the diagram**.

| | **Narration** | The ‘Ranked retention offers’ top-level decision cycles through the list of eligible offers and selects the least expensive one that does not exceed the calculated retention budget for the given customer.

The ‘Retention budget’ sub-decision calculates SkyTalk’s maximum cost that should be spent to keep the customer. The retention budget is calculated using two predictions: (1) customer’s lifetime value, and (2) propensity to churn.

The business analyst uses IBM Watson Studio to create these two predictions. |
**[Go to top](#top)**
3 - Creating the predictive models
| **3.1** | **Show data sources used for prediction** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | The business analyst creates and deploys the machine learning models used to make the predictions. | | **Action**   3.1.1 | Click the **SkyTalk customer retention** project in the Watson Studio project window opened during demo preparation.

| | **Action**   3.1.2 | Click the **Assets** tab. | | **Narration** | Five years of data from SkyTalk’s customer database has already been loaded into IBM Watson Studio. The analyst will use this data to develop predictions for customer lifetime value and churn.

| | **Action**   3.1.3 | Open the **SkyTalk customer loyalty data.csv** file.

| | **Narration** | Watson Studio generates models that predict customer churn. Generating models is referred to as an AutoAI experiment.

The business analyst reviews the historical data file uploaded in Watson Studio to make sure it contains the data required to predict customer churn.

T (true) in the CHURN column indicates the customer closed their SkyTalk account. F (false) indicates the customer remained with SkyTalk. | | **Action**   3.1.4 | Review the displayed **SkyTalk customerloyaltydata.csv** file.

| | **Action**   3.1.5 | Click **SkyTalk customer retention** in the breadcrumb navigation bar.

| | **Narration** | The business analyst starts an AutoAI experiment to create churn prediction models. Watson Studio produces multiple models. In Watson Studio, each model is referred to as a “pipeline.”

The AutoAI tool in Watson Studio analyzes historical data to generate candidate pipelines. | | **Action**   3.1.6 | Click **New AutoAI experiment**.                                              

| | **Action**   3.1.7 | Name the experiment **Churn prediction 2** (1) and click **Create** (2).

| | **Narration** | The analyst selects the customer loyalty data file and selects CHURN in the ‘What do you want to predict’ dropdown menu. | | **Action**   3.1.8 | Click **Select from Project**.

| | **Action**   3.1.9 | Click **Data asset** (1) and then select the **SkyTalk customer loyalty data.xsv** file (2).

| | **Narration** | Various models are automatically developed and tested. The experiment produces a set of pipelines to be reviewed by the business analyst. Then the business analyst selects the algorithm that best fits the prediction quality criteria. | | **Action**   3.1.10 | Click **Select columns** (1) and select **CHURN **(2) as the attribute to predict.

| | **Action**   3.1.11 | Click **Run experiment.**                                              

**Note**: After running the experiment, make sure to wait until the computation is done. It will take about two minutes for the eight pipelines to be ready to explore.

| | **Narration** | In the results, Watson Studio automatically suggested eight candidate pipelines. | | **Action**   3.1.12 | Click **SkyTalk churn prediction** in the **AutoAI experiments** section.

| | **3.2** | **Choose the best predictive model** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | On the ‘Pipeline Comparison’ chart the business analyst examines how each pipeline ranks by various measures of accuracy.

For example, Pipeline 7 is the best model as determined by the ‘Area under the ROC’. Area under the ROC (receiver operating characteristic) measures the pipeline’s accuracy in differentiating useful data from noise. | | **Action**   3.2.1 | Click **Pipeline comparison** (1) and move the cursor over the top curve in the **Area under ROC** column (2) to display the black details box.

| **Narration** | Clicking on a Pipeline provides additional details. | | **Action**   3.2.2 | Scroll down and click **Pipeline 7** in the Pipeline leaderboard.

| **Action**   3.2.3 | Click the **Model evaluation** tab.

| | **Narration** | The ‘Model evaluation’ tab shows results of testing the pipeline. Out of 111 tests, Pipeline 7 returned ten incorrect results: four false positives and six false negatives. This translates to a prediction accuracy of 91%.

The “Confusion matrix” tab shows a more granular view of the test results. | | **Action**   3.2.4 | Click the **Confusion matrix** tab.

| | **Narration** | The analyst compares Pipelines 1 and 7 to understand why Pipeline 1 is rated the best overall. | | **Action**   3.2.5 | Click the **Pipeline details** drop-down list (1) and select **Pipeline 1** (2).

| | **Action**   3.2.6 | Click the **Confusion matrix** tab.

| | **Action**   3.2.7 | Review the **Confusion matrix**. Highlight that the overall correct percentage is higher using Pipeline 1.

| | **Narration** | Pipeline 1 has a higher overall accuracy. The analyst selects Pipeline 1. | | **Action**   3.2.8 | Click the **x** on the upper right-hand side to close the **Pipeline details** view.

| | **Action**   3.2.9 | Click **Save as** in the right-hand side of the Pipeline 1 row.

| | **Action**   3.2.10 | Select **Model** (1) and then click **Create** (2).

| | **Action**   3.2.11 | Click **SkyTalk customer retention** project in the breadcrumb navigation bar.

| | **3.3** | **Expose the model for production use** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | Pipeline 1 is ready to be promoted for use in the churn prediction service in the ‘Retention budget’ sub decision. “Promoting” a pipeline makes it available for use. | | **Action**   3.3.1 | Scroll down and show the two machine learning models.

| | **Action**   3.3.2 | Display the menu on the right-hand side of the model row and click **Promote**.

| | **Narration** | In practice, the analyst would promote the churn model to the deployment environment here. For our demo, it has already been promoted. | | **Action**   3.3.3 | Show the **Skytap production space** (1) option. Click **Cancel** (2) to avoid promoting the model.

**Note**: Do NOT click **Promote**.

| | **Narration** | The two prediction services are now ready for deployment. | | **Action**   3.3.4 | Click the **IBM Watson Studio** menu (1) and then click the **SkyTalk production space** (2).

| | **Action**   3.3.5 | Click the **Deployments** tab.

| | **Narration** | The two services have been deployed.

The service endpoint URL is required to configure a machine learning provider later in the demo. | | **Action**   3.3.6 | Click the **churn** service.

| | **Action**   3.3.7 | Highlight the first portion of the **endpoint URL** for use later in the demo. Only highlight from the beginning through ‘v4’, as shown in the image.

| | **Narration** | The deployment space identifier is also required to configure the machine learning provider. | | **Action**   3.3.8 | Click the **SkyTalk production space** in the breadcrumb navigation bar.

| | **Action**   3.3.9 | Click the **Manage** tab (1) and show the **Space GUID** (2) for use later in the demo.

| **[Go to top](#top)**
4 - Calling the prediction services from the business rules
| **4.1** | **Configure customer retention decision service to use the new predictive services** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | The ‘Retention budget’ sub decision uses the churn and lifetime value predictive services. A machine learning provider establishes the link between the decision and the predictive services.

First, the business analyst sets up a machine learning provider for the ‘Retention budget’ sub decision. | | **Action**   4.1.1 | Return to the **SkyTalk customer retention DS** using the breadcrumb navigation menu.

| | **Action**   4.1.2 | Open the **Settings** menu.

| | **Action**   4.1.3 | Click the **Machine learning providers** tab.

| | **Action**   4.1.4 | Click **Edit** on the right-hand side of the **SkyTalk ML Provider** box.

| | **Action**   4.1.5 | Input the **API key** (1) obtained during demo preparation, the **Space ID** (2), and the Endpoint **URL** (3).

**Note:** The Space GUID saved earlier in the demo is called the Space ID on this interface.

| | **Narration** | The machine learning provider is now configured. The next step is to create a predictive model for the decision to accept the churn prediction output. | | **Action**   4.1.6 | Click **Cancel** and explain that the provider was already set.

| | **Action** 4.1.7 | Return to the **SkyTalk customer retention DS** using the breadcrumb navigation.

| | **Action**   4.1.8 | Click the **SkyTalk initial retention DS** tile.

| | **Action**   4.1.9 | Click **Create**.

| | **Narration** | The business analyst creates a predictive model to accept customer churn prediction output. | | **Action**   4.1.10 | Select **Predictive model** (1) and name it **Customer Churn** (2). Then click **Create** (3).

| | **4.2** | **Connect the predictive service to the predictive model** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | A new predictive model is automatically created. This model needs to be configured to accept the churn prediction output. | | **Action**   4.2.1 | Click **Connect**.

| | **Action**   4.2.2 | Select the **SkyTalk ML provider** created previously in the demo.

| | **Narration** | Select the SkyTalk machine learning provider to establish the link to the churn prediction service. | | **Action**   4.2.3 | Expand the **SkyTalk churn prediction – P1 LGBM Classifier** (1) machine learning model. Then select the **churn** (2) deployment name. The prediction is now connected to the customer lifetime value.

| | **Narration** | Now we will complete the predictive model. A wizard is used to complete the connection. | | **Action**   4.2.4 | Click **Next**.

| | **Action**   4.2.5 | Click **Next**.

| | **Narration** | The input data structure is automatically created. | | **Action**   4.2.6 | Click **Run**.

| | **Narration** | The connection is tested to ensure the predictive service is working. | | **Action**   4.2.7 | Click **Next**.

| | **Action**   4.2.8 | Click **Generate from test output**.

| | **Narration** | The churn predictive service returns true or false and the decision accuracy. This is working as expected. The predictive model is now connected to the ‘Retention budget’ sub decision. | | **Action**   4.2.9 | Click **OK**.

| | **Action**   4.2.10 | Click **Apply**.

| | **Narration** | Now let’s return to the **SkyTalk initial retention DS** using the breadcrumb navigation. | | **Action**   4.2.11 | Click on **SkyTalk initial retention DS** using the breadcrumb navigation menu.

| | **4.3** | **Assign the predictive model to the ‘Retention budget’ decision service** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | Let’s configure the ‘Retention budget’ sub decision to use the churn predictive model. | | **Action**   4.3.1 | Click **Retention offer**.

| | **Action**   4.3.2 | Hover the mouse over the **Retention budget** decision box on the screen.

| | **Action**   4.3.3 | A black choice box appears over the ‘Retention budget’ sub decision. Click the **purple box** to **Add prediction**.



| | **Narration** | The analyst assigns the churn predictive model to the newly created prediction. | | **Action**   4.3.4 | Select the **Prediction 8** node (1) and select the **Customer churn** predictive model. (2)

| | **Action**   4.3.5 | Review The ‘SkyTalk initial retention DS’ decision model that opens.

| | **Narration** | We will need to complete the same steps to create another prediction service for the customer lifetime value predictive model. This has already been created.

Let’s look at the final decision model. | | **Action**   4.3.6 | Return to **SkyTalk customer retention DS** using the breadcrumb navigation menu.

| | **Action**   4.3.7 | Click **SkyTalk retention DS**.

**Note**: Don't use the ‘SkyTalk initial retention DS’ anymore in the scenario

| | **Action**   4.3.8 | Open the **Retention offer** predictive model.

| | **Action**   4.3.9 | Click ** Retention offer**.

| | **Narration** | The analyst can now check the Retention offer business logic. | | **Action**   4.3.10 | Click the **Retention budget** box.

| | **Action**   4.3.11 | Select the **Logic** tab.
| Narration | The retention budget is calculated using the three business rules, displayed in the ‘Rules are applied in sequence’ dropdown menu.

The ‘size importance’ rule calculates the ideal retention budget for this customer. The ‘adjust with cost base rule’ ensures the size importance calculation fits within the overall budget. The ‘output-default-setting’ rule is a default setting if minimum thresholds aren’t met (customer doesn’t qualify for a retention offer). |
**[Go to top](#top)**
5 - Using the automated call center application
| **5.1** | **Generate a real-time retention offer that best allocates SkyTalk’s retention budget** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | SkyTalk used the Cloud Pak to develop an automated call center application that provides agents customer-specific retention offers in real-time.

Let’s look at a how an agent now handles a call from a customer. | | **Action**   5.1.1 | Show the **SkyTalk – Call Center application** preview window opened during demo preparation (see step 10 in the Demo prep instructions).

**Note**: Don’t show that this application in just a preview from Application Designer since it is not in the scope of this demonstration to explain App Designer. | | **Action**   5.1.2 | Enter “Peter Carter” in the **Search Customer** field (1) and click **Search** (2).

| | **Narration** | A customer-specific retention offer is displayed. The agent can suggest this offer to the customer in real-time. | | **Action**   5.1.3 | Click **Get offer**.


| **[Go to top](#top)**
Summary
In this demo, I showed how business users can easily build complex rules that incorporate predictive decisions. The predictions optimally retain SkyTalk’s most important customers by providing customized offers at the lowest cost to SkyTalk.

The new retention process also improved productivity by eliminating manual procedures. Customer satisfaction will increase with speedier and more relevant service.

Thank you for attending today’s presentation.

**Note: At the end of the demonstration**

To be able to follow the same scenario in your next demo, it is important to restore the demo to its initial state:

1. Un-deploy the ML service in the Watson Studio deployment environment to not be charged any more.
2. Return in the SkyTalk initial retention DS and remove:
  a. The Customer Churn predictive model
  b. The Customer Lifetime Value predictive model
  c. The two predictions nodes in the "Retention Offer" decision model
3. Remove the churn experiment in Watson Studio you have created if you have performed the experiment creation phase.
**[Go to top](#top)**

Summary
In this demo, I showed how business users can easily build complex rules that incorporate predictive decisions. The predictions optimally retain SkyTalk’s most important customers by providing customized offers at the lowest cost to SkyTalk.

The new retention process also improved productivity by eliminating manual procedures. Customer satisfaction will increase with speedier and more relevant service.

Thank you for attending today’s presentation.
